comments:
Hello,

I'm a committer on the squirre-sql project on SourceForge and I recently 
started having difficulty committing files using the Team Synchronization
perspective.  When I select a file in the outgoing changes list and access
"Commit" from the context menu, I receive an internal error in a dialog 
with the same text as what I see in the log:

!SESSION 2006-09-02 11:12:29.470 -----------------------------------------------
eclipse.buildId=M20060629-1905
java.version=1.5.0_06
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86, WS=gtk, NL=en_US
Command-line arguments:  -os linux -ws gtk -arch x86 -data /home/manningr/workspace

!ENTRY org.eclipse.team.ui 4 0 2006-09-02 11:16:56.296
!MESSAGE Internal error occurred.
!STACK 0
java.lang.NullPointerException
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ui.mapping.ResourceModelParticipantAction.getTraversals(ResourceModelParticipantAction.java:116)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ui.mapping.ResourceModelParticipantAction.getResourceTraversals(ResourceModelParticipantAction.java:51)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.ui.mappings.CommitAction.access$0(CommitAction.java:1)
        at org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.ui.mappings.CommitAction$1.run(CommitAction.java:78)
        at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run(ModalContext.java:113)


This functionality worked perfectly up until today.  The only change I made 
to Eclipse preferences today was to add junit.jar to the ant home jars.  I 
tried removing it from preferences, but unfortunately, no change in behavior
from the Team synchronization perspective.  Incidentally, I seem to still be
able to commit using the Team context menu in the Java perspective.

Rob Manning

I managed to get past this issue by accessing the "Synchronize CVS" wizard 
and de-selecting the "Java workspace" resource.  I had tried repeatedly to 
re-synchronize both without any luck before.  Not sure if this is relevant 
at all, but I thought it might be useful for someone to know.

Rob

This has been fixed in the 3.2.1 and 3.3 development streams.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 146833 ***

Thanks for pointing that out. Sorry for the dup. But I did a search before 
filing the bug for "ResourceModelParticipantAction.getTraversals" and it 
turned up nothing.  

Also, I thought I had the latest release build of 3.2.  I had no idea that
there was a 3.2.1 release.  Looking at the following page there is still no 
indication that 3.2.1 has been released:

http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/

Now I know that "3.2 Stream Maintenance Build" actually means 3.2.1 
because I connected the dots (I saw this same id in the other bug
posting - M20060830-0800)

I would have downloaded M20060830-0800 (a.k.a 3.2.1) and tested it 
instead of filing the bug if I had known.  Not sure how I would 
change the downloads page to make this more apparent, but I thought 
I'd at least point it out in case someone else has the same problem.  
I'm not sure if this is relevant, but the update manager failed to 
find this update when I ran it (although it did update a couple of 
my plugins)

Rob Manning

Sorry for the confusion of my last comment. I will attempt to clarify. The 3.2.1 release is due sometime in mid to late September. The M (maintenance) builds are similar to I (integration) builds in the sense that they are stable enough to use but are not an official release. In reality, M builds are usually of the same quality as a release build but there are no guarantees of this until the official release occurs. Therefore, I would say that it would be probably be safe for you to upgrade to M20060830-0800 if this problem is stopping you from working (or if you want to help with testing) but, if it is not, you may want to wait for the release. The 3.2.1 build will be available through the update site when it is officially released.

No problem.  I downloaded the "M" build and I'll run that so I can 
provide more relevant feedback in the future.  Thanks for 
clarifying.

Rob
